gallery.title: Moisture Reading on Door/Window
gallery.description: Testing moisture levels on thresholds and windows to detect subsurface termite activity. Professional moisture detection is critical for identifying hidden termite infestations before they cause major damage.

gallery.title: Termite Swarmers
gallery.description: Discarded wings from termite reproductives (swarmers). These wings are a key sign of termite activity and help distinguish termites from flying ants. Swarmers emerge to start new colonies, typically in spring.

gallery.title: Infrared Thermal Imaging
gallery.description: Advanced thermal imaging camera technology used to detect termites and moisture within walls without invasive inspection. This cutting-edge equipment allows us to find hidden infestations that traditional methods might miss.

gallery.title: Termite-Damaged Wood
gallery.description: Soldier termites protecting compromised shelter tubes from ant invasion. This image shows the extent of damage termites can cause to wooden structures and the importance of early detection and treatment.

gallery.title: Shelter Tube in Insulation
gallery.description: An unusual shelter tube emerging from insulation after hardwood floor destruction. Termites build these mud tubes to travel between their colony and food sources while protecting themselves from predators and dry air.

gallery.title: Flying Ant vs. Termite Comparison
gallery.description: Educational comparison chart showing the distinguishing features between flying ants and termite swarmers. Key differences include antenna shape (bent vs. straight), waist size (pinched vs. broad), and wing size (unequal vs. equal).
